title: Psychology Taster Lecture
section: Prepare for a journey through Mind-Space!
text:
Prepare for a journey through Mind-Space!

Forget everything you thought you knew about understanding people
I‚Äôm about to revolutionize your view of social interaction
Welcome to the wild world of Mind-space!

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Introducing Mind-space


Every person‚Äôs mind exists in a multidimensional space
It‚Äôs like the Marvel multiverse, but for brains!
Minds are mapped based on traits, abilities, and quirks
YOU are constantly navigating this mind-boggling terrain

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
The Power of Mind-space


Not just abstract theory - the key to unlocking human behavior!
Every time you:

Size someone up
Predict their actions
Wonder ‚ÄúWhat were they thinking?!‚Äù

You‚Äôre tapping into the awesome power of Mind-space!

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
section: For any AI geeks out there‚Ä¶ üíõ
text:
For any AI geeks out there‚Ä¶ üíõ

It‚Äôs essentially the same idea as Embeddings in VectorSpace in LLMs
But we do it WAY better, and potentially faster!

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Systematic Observation in Natural Settings

Street Psychology
Observing behavior without interference
Identifying patterns and anomalies
Real-life Psychological Profiling
Inferring meaning and motive in everyday behaviour

title: About
text:
About this site

# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(tidyr)

# Sample data for the chart
data <- data.frame(
  AgeGroup = c("60-77", "45-60", "30-44", "18-29", "13-17", "8-12", "6-8"),
  MoreThanFiveLies = c(1, 3, 4, 10, 11, 9, 9),
  OneToFiveLies = c(10, 13, 28, 35, 45, 43, 43),
  NoLies = c(89, 84, 68, 55, 45, 48, 48)
)

# Reshape the data for plotting
data_long <- data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c("MoreThanFiveLies", "OneToFiveLies", "NoLies"),
               names_to = "LieFrequency",
               values_to = "Percentage")

# Define the order of the factors for AgeGroup and LieFrequency
data_long$AgeGroup <- factor(data_long$AgeGroup, levels = rev(data$AgeGroup))
data_long$LieFrequency <- factor(data_long$LieFrequency, 
                                 levels = c("NoLies", "OneToFiveLies", "MoreThanFiveLies"))

# Improved color palette
color_palette <- c("#d9d9d9", "#969696", "#525252")  # Light to dark grey

# Create the stacked bar plot
ggplot(data_long, aes(x = AgeGroup, y = Percentage, fill = LieFrequency)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "stack", width = 0.7) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = color_palette) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Lying frequency, by age", subtitle = "Over a 24-hour period", 
       x = "Age Group", y = "Percentage of Lies", fill = "Lies Frequency") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "top", 
        plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.title = element_blank()) +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(Percentage, "%")), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5), 
            size = 3, color = "white")









# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)

# Sample data for the chart
data <- data.frame(
  AgeGroup = c("60-77", "45-60", "30-44", "18-29", "13-17", "8-12", "6-8"),
  MoreThanFiveLies = c(1, 3, 4, 10, 11, 9, 9),
  OneToFiveLies = c(10, 13, 28, 35, 45, 43, 43),
  NoLies = c(89, 84, 68, 55, 45, 48, 48)
)

# Reshape the data for plotting
data_long <- data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c("MoreThanFiveLies", "OneToFiveLies", "NoLies"),
               names_to = "LieFrequency",
               values_to = "Percentage")

# Define the order of the factors for AgeGroup and LieFrequency
data_long$AgeGroup <- factor(data_long$AgeGroup, levels = rev(data$AgeGroup))
data_long$LieFrequency <- factor(data_long$LieFrequency, 
                                 levels = c("NoLies", "OneToFiveLies", "MoreThanFiveLies"))

# Updated pastel color palette
color_palette <- c("#f2f2f2", "#f7c6c7", "#FFEB84")  # Light grey, pastel pink, pastel yellow for 5+

# Create the stacked bar plot
p <- ggplot(data_long, aes(x = AgeGroup, y = Percentage, fill = LieFrequency)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "stack", width = 0.7) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = color_palette) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Lying frequency, by age", subtitle = "Over a 24-hour period", 
       x = "Age Group", y = "Percentage of Lies", fill = "Lies Frequency") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "top", 
        plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.title = element_blank()) +
  geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(LieFrequency == "NoLies", paste0(Percentage, "%"), "")), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5), 
            size = 3, color = "black") +  # Black text for "No Lies"
  geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(LieFrequency != "NoLies", paste0(Percentage, "%"), "")), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5), 
            size = 3, color = "black")  # White text for other categories

# Display the plot
print(p)

title: MarshMallows
text:
Welcome!

Psychology at Goldsmiths
Where science meets creativity

title: MarshMallows
section: Overview of Y1 Psychology at Goldsmiths
text:
Overview of Y1 Psychology at Goldsmiths


Term 1 Modules - Introduction to Psychology - Research Methods & Statistics I - Biological & Comparative Approaches - Cognitive Psychology

Term 2 Modules - Social Psychology - Developmental Psychology - Individual Differences - Applied Psychology


Emphasize our unique strengths: - Critical approach to psychology - Integration of scientific rigor with creative thinking - Strong focus on research skills from day one

title: MarshMallows
text:
Are You Ready for University?

Time ManagementIndependent LearningAcademic Skills



How do you currently organize your studies?
Can you manage multiple deadlines without supervision?
Do you have systems for tracking your work?




How do you find information beyond what‚Äôs provided?
Can you evaluate sources critically?
How comfortable are you with ambiguity?




How confident are you with academic writing?
Can you construct a coherent argument?
Are you comfortable with statistical concepts?

title: MarshMallows
text:
How University Differs from School



School
University




Teacher-directed learning
Self-directed learning


Regular homework checks
Independent deadlines


Structured timetable
Flexible schedule with gaps


Information provided
Research expected


Focus on correct answers
Focus on critical analysis


Limited reading list
Extensive reading beyond lectures

title: MarshMallows
text:
Your Psychology Journey

What brings you to psychology?

title: MarshMallows
text:
Your End Goals

What do you want from your psychology degree?



Career preparation?
Understanding human behavior?
Research skills?
Personal development?
Something else?

title: MarshMallows
text:
Today‚Äôs Experiment: The Marshmallow Challenge






The Task


Build the tallest free-standing structure using: - 20 sticks of spaghetti - 1 yard of tape - 1 yard of string - 1 marshmallow (must be on top!) - Time limit: 18 minutes

title: MarshMallows
text:
Pre-Challenge Psychology Connections


Group dynamics: How do strangers form working relationships?
Social facilitation vs.¬†social loafing
In-group formation
Status and power dynamics
Cognitive biases:
Functional fixedness (seeing objects only for their intended use)
Planning fallacy (underestimating time needed)
Overconfidence effect
Decision-making under pressure:
Impact of stress on cognitive performance
Satisficing vs.¬†optimizing strategies

title: MarshMallows
text:
Predictions






Think-Pair-Share



Which type of group performs best in this challenge?
Business executives
Recent MBA graduates
Engineers and architects
Kindergarten children
Why do you think this is the case?

title: MarshMallows
text:
Research Methods Preview
This challenge demonstrates core elements of psychological research:


Variables:
Independent (group composition)
Dependent (tower height, completion)
Control (same materials, instructions)
Observation methods:
Structured observation
Behavioral coding
Process analysis
Data analysis:
Quantitative (height measurements)
Qualitative (group dynamics)

title: MarshMallows
text:
Observer Roles
Some of you will be observers rather than participants:


Communication patterns:
Who speaks? How often? Who listens?
Verbal vs.¬†non-verbal communication
Decision-making processes:
How are ideas generated and evaluated?
Is there evidence of groupthink?
Leadership emergence:
Formal vs.¬†informal leadership
Leadership styles (directive, participative)
Conflict resolution:
How are disagreements handled?
Constructive vs.¬†destructive conflict

title: MarshMallows
text:
Now, Let‚Äôs Begin!

18:00 minutes on the clock‚Ä¶

title: MarshMallows
text:
Post-Challenge Analysis
Tuckman‚Äôs Stages of Group Development


Forming: Orientation, testing boundaries
Storming: Conflict, resistance to task demands
Norming: Development of group cohesion
Performing: Functional role relatedness
Adjourning: Completion and disengagement

title: MarshMallows
text:
Cognitive Biases in Action






What we observed








Planning fallacy: Groups overestimated what they could accomplish
Functional fixedness: Limited vision of how materials could be used
Overconfidence bias: Initial certainty vs.¬†final outcomes
Sunk cost fallacy: Continuing with failing approaches

title: MarshMallows
text:
Stress and Creativity



Yerkes-Dodson Law: Optimal arousal
Time pressure effects on divergent thinking
Impact of evaluation apprehension
Stress responses: Fight, flight, or freeze in team contexts

title: MarshMallows
text:
Psychology Careers Connection

Organizational PsychologyClinical PsychologyDevelopmental Psychology



Team effectiveness assessment
Leadership development
Workplace interventions
Change management




Group therapy dynamics
Behavioral observation
Interpersonal functioning
Stress responses




Age differences in approach
Learning through play
Concrete vs.¬†abstract thinking
Social development

title: MarshMallows
text:
The Research Behind the Challenge


Collaborative problem-solving:
Coordination costs vs.¬†diversity benefits
Psychological safety (Edmondson, 1999)
Creative thinking principles:
Divergent vs.¬†convergent thinking phases
Prototype testing and iteration
Mindset research:
Fixed vs.¬†growth mindset (Dweck)
Impact on persistence and approach to failure

title: MarshMallows
text:
The Kindergarten Advantage






Why children often outperform business students:








Rapid prototyping - testing early and often
No status management or impression concerns
Learning through play - less fear of failure
Less fixated on ‚Äúone right way‚Äù to solve problems
Natural collaboration without hierarchy

title: MarshMallows
text:
Follow-up Activity: Design Your Experiment






In groups, design a variation of this challenge to test:








How would you modify the challenge to test a specific psychological variable?
What would you measure and how?
What hypotheses would you propose?
What interventions might improve performance?

title: MarshMallows
text:
What‚Äôs Next?


Complete our welcome day feedback form
Join the Psychology Society
Explore the campus
Connect with your peer mentors
Follow @GoldsmithsPsych on social media



Any questions?

title: MarshMallows
text:
Thank You!

We look forward to welcoming you in September!
